newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian economic indicators give mixed picture.
newsitem.headline: Russian economic indicators give mixed picture.

text.p: The Russian economy continued to stabilise in March but problems remain, official figures released Monday showed.
"The great decline in the Russian economy over the last decade has practically stopped," Yuri Yurkov, chairman of the State Statistics Committee, told a news conference.
Russian gross domestic product rose 0.2 percent in the first quarter from a year ago and consumer price inflation in March slowed to a post-reform low of 16.7 percent, the figures showed.
Officials point to such figures as evidence of a turnaround in the Russian economy, which has shrunk every year since 1989.
Yurkov said the figures should not be interpreted as showing economic growth, but said they indicated the economy was no longer contracting.
But the picture may not be as rosy as it seems. GDP actually fell 0.3 percent in March from a year ago and other problems persist.
The unemployment rate rose to 9.6 percent in March according to official figures and actual unemployment is widely considered to be even higher.
